properties.Name: CollectionLetter
properties.Description:
A collection letter that is sent.

Larger companies frequently issue collection letters.

At a minimum, you should send a duplicate bill each month.
Handwriting gives a personal contact that can be very effective.

Collection letters should always mention that the Customer is to disregard the letter if the payment has already been made.

As a rule-of-thumb, a business should get firmer after 60 days, three or more contacts or a history of problems in dealing with the Customer.

Columns.Name: CollectionEventId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a collection event.

Columns.Name: CollectionLetterText
Columns.Description: The text contents of the collection letter.

Columns.Name: RequiredResponseDate
Columns.Description: The date that a required response was indicated in the collection letter.

Columns.Name: ResponseDescription
Columns.Description: A description of the Legal Entity response to the collection letter.

Columns.Name: OutstandingAmount
Columns.Description: The amount of debt outstanding at the time of the collection letter.

Columns.Name: CollectedAmount
Columns.Description: The amount collected or pledged in response to the collection letter.

Columns.Name: CollectionLetterTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of the Collection Letter Type.

Columns.Name: FollowupCollectionActivityId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Followup Collection Activity Type.

Properties.Description:
A collection letter that is sent.

Larger companies frequently issue collection letters.

At a minimum, you should send a duplicate bill each month.
Handwriting gives a personal contact that can be very effective.

Collection letters should always mention that the Customer is to disregard the letter if the payment has already been made.

As a rule-of-thumb, a business should get firmer after 60 days, three or more contacts or a history of problems in dealing with the Customer.
